story:
About the Book

This gloriously illustrated children's book illuminates contemporary mixed race life from the point of view of a child. A much needed volume, The Biracial Butterfly shows the beauty and magic of identity, and celebrates the lives of interracial families today.

About the Author

Lennox Benson was born to a teacher and a doctor in Lagos, Nigeria and migrated to London, UK at the age of two.

Raised by his mother, he was gifted many books and became a keen reader. In primary school, he excelled in art and creative writing, and secretly nurtured a dream to write a book of his own one day.

These creative skills were carried into secondary school where he achieved good grades in Art and English. He then went on to study English, Art & Theatre Studies at A level before securing a place at Queen Mary University to study English Literature.

However, after a term at Queen Mary, he found himself unsure of his place in the world as a young, gay black man and left to find himself. He made a concerted effort to look for Black British mentors who could provide some guidance in making sense of his world.

After some months of networking he garnered the support of a few experienced professionals who were able to guide him through this crucial transition from his late teenage years to early adulthood.

After years of trying his hand with different art mediums including acting and dancing, he returned to writing and began work on his first children’s book The Biracial Butterfly.

What We Need & What You Get

This is book is going to be made, whatever happens. However, with your support we can give the book the love it needs. If we successfully fund this project, we'll be able to provide high quality print copies for backers and send copies to schools and reviewers.

Our aim is to provide a mirror for biracial families, who are so often overlooked in today's publishing landscape, and to provide much needed representation for mixed race children.

In return for supporting us, you get great benefits such as:

  • A signed first edition, first printing copy of The Biracial Butterfly
  • A shoutout in the backers' section of the book
  • Our love and respect
  • The warm, fuzzy glow of knowing you're helping to raise visibility for biracial families

The Impact

We're not asking for much. We have a skilled team working on this book, and we're determined to put this book out there. But what we really need is money to help support our promotional and marketing efforts, and that's where you come in. Your money will help us spread the word about the book, to contact schools and libraries to set up readings around the country, and to submit the book to festivals and prizes.

Anyone can publish a book via print on demand, but making your book stand out against the sea of new titles is hard - and that's what we're looking to do.

Risks & Challenges

Between us, we have experience in media production, marketing and publishing. The book has been written and fully illustrated. The images are being converted to a print-ready file as we speak. The cover is being laid out. The book will be heading to print in 2018 - make no mistake about it.

Dog Horn Publishing has been publishing titles for over a decade. Our books are distributed via NBN International, and represented by Inpress Books, the leading sales and marketing agency for independent presses in the UK. Our titles are available via Amazon, Waterstones and most major retailers, and you can request them in your local library too. We also produce ebook editions available on Kindle, Nook, B&N and Overdrive.

But we're a small venture lacking in people power. For £2,500, we can afford to inject some essential PR and marketing time into the mix. What's more, we can produce extra copies of the book to send to key reviewers, librarians and teachers - which will all raise the visibility of the book.

It's our hope that we get Lennox into schools to read from his book, and to get copies into the hands of the children and parents who'd appreciate them most. We want biracial children to feel they can be the protagonists of their own stories and to see their lives reflected in the literature they read.

As with all Indiegogo campaigns, there will be an element of risk. In this case, however, the risks are few. While it's feasible that real-life problems, unexpected technical issues or an accident with printing might delay publication, the hard work has already been done, so the book will be published in one form or another whatever happens.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute financially, there are other ways you can help. You can:

  • Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about our campaign.
  • Offer to signal boost our PR efforts by sharing and retweeting any press coverage or reviews you see.
  • Request a copy of the book from your local library (you can order the book via its ISBN, and the library will source one for you).
  • Ask your local school to contact us to arrange an author visit.
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools!

And that's all there is to it.

Lennox Benson was born to a teacher and a doctor in Lagos, Nigeria and migrated to London, UK at the age of two.
Raised by his mother, he was gifted many books and became a keen reader. In primary school, he excelled in art and creative writing, and secretly nurtured a dream to write a book of his own one day.
These creative skills were carried into secondary school where he achieved good grades in Art and English. He then went on to study English, Art & Theatre Studies at A level before securing a place at Queen Mary University to study English Literature.
However, after a term at Queen Mary, he found himself unsure of his place in the world as a young, gay black man and left to find himself. He made a concerted effort to look for Black British mentors who could provide some guidance in making sense of his world.
After some months of networking he garnered the support of a few experienced professionals who were able to guide him through this crucial transition from his late teenage years to early adulthood.
After years of trying his hand with different art mediums including acting and dancing, he returned to writing and began work on his first children’s book The Biracial Butterfly.

What We Need & What You Get
This is book is going to be made, whatever happens. However, with your support we can give the book the love it needs. If we successfully fund this project, we'll be able to provide high quality print copies for backers and send copies to schools and reviewers.
Our aim is to provide a mirror for biracial families, who are so often overlooked in today's publishing landscape, and to provide much needed representation for mixed race children.
In return for supporting us, you get great benefits such as:

A signed first edition, first printing copy of The Biracial Butterfly

A shoutout in the backers' section of the book
Our love and respect
The warm, fuzzy glow of knowing you're helping to raise visibility for biracial families


The Impact
We're not asking for much. We have a skilled team working on this book, and we're determined to put this book out there. But what we really need is money to help support our promotional and marketing efforts, and that's where you come in. Your money will help us spread the word about the book, to contact schools and libraries to set up readings around the country, and to submit the book to festivals and prizes.
Anyone can publish a book via print on demand, but making your book stand out against the sea of new titles is hard - and that's what we're looking to do.

Risks & Challenges
Between us, we have experience in media production, marketing and publishing. The book has been written and fully illustrated. The images are being converted to a print-ready file as we speak. The cover is being laid out. The book will be heading to print in 2018 - make no mistake about it.
Dog Horn Publishing has been publishing titles for over a decade. Our books are distributed via NBN International, and represented by Inpress Books, the leading sales and marketing agency for independent presses in the UK. Our titles are available via Amazon, Waterstones and most major retailers, and you can request them in your local library too. We also produce ebook editions available on Kindle, Nook, B&N and Overdrive.
But we're a small venture lacking in people power. For £2,500, we can afford to inject some essential PR and marketing time into the mix. What's more, we can produce extra copies of the book to send to key reviewers, librarians and teachers - which will all raise the visibility of the book.
It's our hope that we get Lennox into schools to read from his book, and to get copies into the hands of the children and parents who'd appreciate them most. We want biracial children to feel they can be the protagonists of their own stories and to see their lives reflected in the literature they read.
As with all Indiegogo campaigns, there will be an element of risk. In this case, however, the risks are few. While it's feasible that real-life problems, unexpected technical issues or an accident with printing might delay publication, the hard work has already been done, so the book will be published in one form or another whatever happens.

Other Ways You Can Help
If you can't contribute financially, there are other ways you can help. You can:

Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about our campaign.
Offer to signal boost our PR efforts by sharing and retweeting any press coverage or reviews you see.
Request a copy of the book from your local library (you can order the book via its ISBN, and the library will source one for you).
Ask your local school to contact us to arrange an author visit.
Use the Indiegogo share tools!

And that's all there is to it.

story:
ABOUT THE PROJECT

  • This project is about expanding my readership but first and foremost the publication of a new book, HUMOR, LAUGHTER & LIFE, which I believe will have the most comprehensive collection of jokes and anecdotes ever compiled. Should this project be successful I will follow it by publishing paperback versions of my current ebooks including my recipe books which I believe are in a class of their own and my autobiography which will interest anyone who would like to learn how one member of the “the other half” lived in the years from 1941 to date.
  • So far only my joke books have been printed and I have sold 6000 copies of the printed versions as a self-publisher but if I am to support myself I need to expand my readership of my existing eBooks, include print versions of my other books in my portfolio and write the new book HUMOR, LAUGHTER & LIFE,. To do this I need your help.

ABOUT THE AUTHOR

  • My name is Chris Bruce. I retired in 2012 but on 31st July 2014 I became comatose and was diagnosed with End Stage Kidney Failure. After two months in hospital and a year of medical treatment I have exhausted my savings and am now having to rely on my family for financial support. I have launched this campaign to try to expand my readership enough to provide me with some self-support and to give my wife and family some relief from the burden of supporting my medical care. Before my diagnosis I had limited writing success having written 8 joke books, 6 recipe books and an autobiography but, being limited, my success has not been enough to support my extremely expensive medical treatment. Writing is the only way that I can now earn a living. Fortunately I enjoy being an author and it’s my hope that by continuing to write I will be able to relieve my family of some of the burden I have imposed on them and live a little longer! To this end I am writing a new book named HUMOR, LAUGHTER & LIFE. 

WHY JOKE AND RECIPE BOOKS AND AN AUTOBIOGRAPHY?

  • I inherited my sense of humor from my mother who would find something funny or ironic in almost any situation, good or bad. I’ve never been any good at telling jokes or repeating anecdotes whether my own or by others but I have been good at collecting and recording them and, by compiling the joke books, I have been able to give others the opportunity to both enjoy and re-tell the jokes. Whether clean or “risqué/adult”, in context the jokes I have collected have been carefully selected for their funniness. Risqué or slightly smutty jokes you will find in all my “adult” books but not jokes of a gratuitous or salacious nature. Funniness is always the criteria for all jokes.
  •  Well, what about your recipe books you may ask? These all stem from my ventures into producing both fresh and processed sausage in restaurants I had an interest in and a sausage factory I built and operated in the course of my long career. I had to research, record and adapt hundreds of recipes for both the restaurants and the factory and it is these recipes upon which my sausage making and recipe books are based.

  • I also developed an interest in making liqueurs in Thailand, inspired by the wide variety of fruit there. I developed liqueur recipes and tested them but never managed to establish a factory due to impossible regulation requirements and the huge amount of money required to fund it.

  • Finally, my life has been a very interesting, if not very financially rewarding, one. I was born in England, emigrated to Namibia, went to university in South Africa, started a construction company in Namibia and built numerous buildings under fire during the South African/Angolan Border war, learnt to fly and had a long career working in 7 countries. I have lived through some of the most important events in world history in recent times and I’ve correlated these events with the history of my life. My autobiography is an unusual one.

WHY I NEED YOUR HELP

  • Besides the jokes already published and printed in my books I have hundreds more, as yet unpublished, jokes and anecdotes that have provided me personally with hours of entertainment. I want to publish a selection of the best jokes in one book with numerous, easily referenced, categories thus giving as many people as possible the opportunity to relax a little with a book of really funny jokes, anecdotes and tall tales and to provide a source of really good humorous matériel for use in speeches and at social occasions of every description. The book is named HUMOR, LAUGHTER & LIFE. Even if you can’t contribute financially you can send me a joke or anecdote for inclusion and acknowledgement in the book. I will even include your name in a joke; with your permission of course. In this new book readers will be able to find a joke in any category ranging from the oddities of the English language to riotous religion and everything in between. 
  • My recipe books have only been published as eBooks. While these have been well received as digital books they are not in an ideal format to work with in the kitchen. The kitchen is one area where it is not advisable to have your e-reader, iPad or laptop lying around. I would very much like to get print versions of these books made.
  • My autobiography, Autobiography of an Unknown Man, has been very well received by the few people who have read it, all of whom have encouraged me to publish it because of the insight it gives into an unusual life lived through 75 years of world history in some very unfamiliar places. This book will appeal to autobiography aficionados. I hope that one day I will be able to have it printed.
  • As most of you will know, publishing is not for the faint hearted. It is a very difficult and time consuming business and as a result many great or interesting works never see the light of day. 
  • I have some paperback copies of some, but not all, of my joke books in stock and am offering these as perks but the shipping cost makes these a little expensive so I am also offering digital versions of all my books as a much cheaper option even if you decide to print them out on your personal printer.

PERKS

  • $6 The eBook versions of all three Plain Funny books for the family. (3 books) A discount of 33% on the published versions. Free transmission.
  • $6 The eBook versions of the two Funny But Risqué books and Great Jokes for Grandpa to Tell for adults. (3 books) A discount of 33% on the published versions. Free transmission.
  • $8 The eBook versions of The Connoisseur’s Guide to Making Liqueurs Vols. I & II (2 books). A discount of 20% on the published versions. Free transmission.
  • $8 The eBook versions of The Gourmet’s Guide to Making Sausage Vols. I & II (2 books). A discount of 20% on the published versions. Free transmission.
  • $16 The eBook versions of all four recipe books. (4 books) A discount of 20% on the published versions. Free transmission.
  • $28 The eBook versions of Plain Funny, Plain Funny Too, Plain Family Fun, Autobiography of an Unknown Man, The Connoisseur’s Guide to Making Liqueurs Vols. I & II, The Gourmet’s Guide to making Sausage Vols. I & II Sausage: Making a Meal of It and The Gourmet’s Guide to Making Meat Loaves and Hamburger Patties. (10 books) A discount of 20%-33% on the published versions. Free transmission.
  • $28 The eBook versions of Funny But Risqué, Funny But Risqué Too, Great Jokes for Grandpa to Tell, Autobiography of an Unknown Man, The Connoisseur’s Guide to Making Liqueurs Vols. I & II, The Gourmet’s Guide to making Sausage Vols. I & II Sausage: Making a Meal of It and The Gourmet’s Guide to Making Meat Loaves and Hamburger Patties. (10 books) A discount of 20%-33% on the published versions. Free transmission.
  • $7 The paperback version of Plain Funny. A discount of 20% on the published versions. Add $8 for shipping to the USA and all other countries.
  • $12 The paperback version of Plain Funny. Signed by the author. A discount of 20% on the published versions. Add $8 for shipping to the USA and all other countries.
  • $7 The paperback version of Funny But Risqué. A discount of 33% on the published versions. Add $8 for shipping to the USA and all other countries.
  • $12 The paperback version of Funny But Risqué. Signed by the author. A discount of 33% on the published versions. Add $8 for shipping to the USA and all other countries.
  • $7 The paperback version of Funny But Risqué Too. A discount of 33% on the published versions. Add $8 for shipping to the USA and all other countries.
  • $12 The paperback version of Funny But Risqué Too. Signed by the author. A discount of 33% on the published versions. Add $8 for shipping to the USA and all other countries.
  • $7 The paperback version of Golfing Stories. A discount of 33% on the published versions. Add $8 for shipping to the USA and all other countries.
  • $12 The paperback version of Golfing Stories. Signed by the author. A discount of 33% on the published version. Add $8 for shipping to the USA and all other countries.
  • $7 The paperback version of Gay Tales. A discount of 33% on the published version. Add $8 for shipping to the USA and all other countries.
  • $12 The paperback version of Gay Tales. Signed by the author. A discount of 33% on the published version. Add $8 for shipping to the USA and all other countries.
  • $60 All five paperback versions of Plain Funny, Funny But Risqué, Funny But Risqué Too, Golfing Stories and Gay Tales. All signed by the Author. Add $30 for shipping to the USA and all other countries.
  • $100 YOUR SELECTION: Of any or all of my EBOOKS (Transmission at the end of this campaign.) PLUS an Early Bird signed copy of HUMOR, LAUGHTER & LIFE (Expected delivery in December 2015) and an eBook version as soon as the book is complete. 
  • $10 FEATURE: Be featured in HUMOR, LAUGHTER & LIFE in a joke or anecdote of your choice.

JUST $8000 CAN BRING HUMOR, LAUGHTER & LIFE TO PUBLICATION

  • This edition will be limited to a print run of 1000 copies. The majority of the funding, $5000, will go towards editing, printing, marketing, distribution and shipping of the book plus Indiegogo fees. Any extra funds over my goal will be used to help support my medical costs while I write the book.
  • I hope to reach my goal and have the book printed and distributed by December. Humor, Laughter & Life will make a great gift at Christmas time! 

Risks & Challenges

My printer has already proved his reliability with the printing of short runs of the paperbacks he has previously printed for me. I expect to complete the book by early November, have it printed by 30th November and mailed by the beginning of December. However, as with any publishing project there can be unforeseen delays or setbacks. I will certainly work extremely hard to get this book to my backers on time. Should there be any delay or setback to my delivery schedule I will keep you posted.

What else can you do to help?

OTHER THAN PLEDGING YOU CAN SHARE MY CAMPAIGN BY:
  • Telling your family and friends about this campaign.
  • Broadcasting campaign details on Facebook, Twitter and other social media.
  • Contributing your jokes and anecdotes to chrisbruce41@gmail .com and in return having them credited to you in the new book; HUMOR, LAUGHTER, LIFE.

PLEASE DONATE NOW AND HELP ME TO BRING THIS NEW BOOK TO LIFE.

story:
I'm a writer at heart. I've written award-winning short stories, composed four high school songs with complete orchestration, and now I've written a great AMERICAN NOVEL that is yearning to get in the hands of readers!

You can be part of this great adventure. When the book comes out and is a best seller, you will have bragging rights that you helped publish the book! Seldom do people have an opportunity like this!!! A portion of book earnings will go to charity.

In these times, big book publishers won't support new authors like they used to, so all the heavy lifting of publishing, editing, marketing falls on the author. And this book is too compelling to resist! People are clamoring for it.

Already, best-selling authors have read the book even before it's been published and are singing its praises. People who've read just a portion of the book are asking, "WHEN IS THE MOVIE COMING OUT?!!!"

Check out the website curtlocklearauthor.com and watch the book video trailer and see if you can resist being part of this marvelous endeavor!  Costs: Basic printing $3300, editing $1300, Kindle version $200, Marketing and misc. $3200. Expect transparency on the book's progress.

story:
The Story of Buddy

Buddy the Soldier Bear is the endearing story of a lonely stuffed bear who sits on a shelf in a toy store dreaming of being part of a family and going on adventures. After a long wait, he is bought by a kind old lady who packs him in a care package and sends him to a deployed soldier. The soldier and his comrades take Buddy on many adventures and he eventually goes home with the soldier and becomes part of a family. All of Buddy's dreams come true! We want to inspire children to dream big! Buddy the Soldier bear is so much more than just a book and stuffed animal - it's a movement! Join #BuddysArmy! 

This charming tale is the debut of Marie Joy Monroe, the daughter of a WW II veteran and mother of a young man (Ryan Monroe) who served in the Army in Iraq and Afghanistan. Throughout his several deployments, Marie and her grassroots organization, Operation Hugs From Home, sent 1000's of care packages and letters to soldiers over the years. Marie's goal was always to make the soldiers feel appreciated, and as if they were receiving a literal hug from home. 

One of the soldiers who was deployed with Marie's son and received care packages and letters from Marie was Brandon Pollard, the illustrator who brought Buddy to life. Brandon is out of the Army now, and recently graduated from the Portland Art Institute. He is immensely talented. His depiction of Buddy and the adventures he went on with the soldiers could only truly be illustrated by a veteran who had served himself. 

Marie no longer runs Operation Hugs From Home, but has instead opted to join ranks with the Central AZ3 Blue Star Moms, her local chapter of Blue Star Mothers of America. With them, she still regularly packs care packages which are shipped to soldiers on a monthly basis. Marie's hope is to get Buddy printed and many of the stuffed bears made. A portion of the profits will go to Central AZ3 Blue Star Moms and other nonprofit organizations who help soldiers in some manner. She hopes to also partner with an organization that helps soldiers with PTSD. It's her passion to help soldiers and show them how much we care. With your help, we can launch the book and stuffed bear and help many of our brave warriors. The book also talks about dreams coming true and Marie hopes to inspire children to dream BIG and let them know that their dreams can come true. 

Please help us to achieve our goal! Even a small donation will help! 

What We Need

Our goal is $25,000. Yes, that sounds like a lot of money, but printing books is expensive and having a stuffed animal made in the USA is even more expensive. Marie is passionate about not outsourcing the manufacturing to another country and wants to keep those jobs at home! With the $25,000, we can get 1,000 paperback books printed, 500 hard cover books printed, 1,000 stuffed bears made, invest in some marketing, and throw a fabulous launch party. If we exceed our goal, our stretch goal is $50,000. With that, we will be able to donate books to public libraries, schools, and military support groups. If we exceed the stretch goal, we will definitely have even more books printed, bears made, and items such as t-shirts, bookmarks, stickers, coloring books, and other Buddy memorabilia. We'd also love suggestions from our fans with ideas for other Buddy merchandise. The more money we are able to raise, the more books will also be donated to public libraries and schools. 

Perks

We are offering perks for the various donation levels which are noted in the Perks section. 

How You Can Help

If you're unable to contribute, we ask that you please get the word out. Share the campaign on your social media pages, talk to your friends and family about it. Even $5-$10 helps! It all adds up. Be a part of the Buddy movement and join "BuddysArmy. Buddy's story needs to get out! We want to help as many soldiers as we can! Thank you for your help! We couldn't do it without you and we are truly humbled by the outpouring of support and positivity already! Thank you from the bottom of our hearts!

Hugs,

Marie Joy Monroe and Brandon Pollard

A special thanks to Todd Gessele and Gioni Birkenfeld of Totally Inspired Media who filmed and edited the video for this crowd funding campaign! We couldn't have done it without you, Todd and Gioni!
story_txt:
The Story of Buddy Buddy the Soldier Bear is the endearing story of a lonely stuffed bear who sits on a shelf in a toy store dreaming of being part of a family and going on adventures. After a long wait, he is bought by a kind old lady who packs him in a care package and sends him to a deployed soldier. The soldier and his comrades take Buddy on many adventures and he eventually goes home with the soldier and becomes part of a family. All of Buddy's dreams come true! We want to inspire children to dream big! Buddy the Soldier bear is so much more than just a book and stuffed animal - it's a movement! Join #BuddysArmy! 
This charming tale is the debut of Marie Joy Monroe, the daughter of a WW II veteran and mother of a young man (Ryan Monroe) who served in the Army in Iraq and Afghanistan. Throughout his several deployments, Marie and her grassroots organization, Operation Hugs From Home, sent 1000's of care packages and letters to soldiers over the years. Marie's goal was always to make the soldiers feel appreciated, and as if they were receiving a literal hug from home. 
One of the soldiers who was deployed with Marie's son and received care packages and letters from Marie was Brandon Pollard, the illustrator who brought Buddy to life. Brandon is out of the Army now, and recently graduated from the Portland Art Institute. He is immensely talented. His depiction of Buddy and the adventures he went on with the soldiers could only truly be illustrated by a veteran who had served himself. 
Marie no longer runs Operation Hugs From Home, but has instead opted to join ranks with the Central AZ3 Blue Star Moms, her local chapter of Blue Star Mothers of America. With them, she still regularly packs care packages which are shipped to soldiers on a monthly basis. Marie's hope is to get Buddy printed and many of the stuffed bears made. A portion of the profits will go to Central AZ3 Blue Star Moms and other nonprofit organizations who help soldiers in some manner. She hopes to also partner with an organization that helps soldiers with PTSD. It's her passion to help soldiers and show them how much we care. With your help, we can launch the book and stuffed bear and help many of our brave warriors. The book also talks about dreams coming true and Marie hopes to inspire children to dream BIG and let them know that their dreams can come true. 
Please help us to achieve our goal! Even a small donation will help!    What We Need Our goal is $25,000. Yes, that sounds like a lot of money, but printing books is expensive and having a stuffed animal made in the USA is even more expensive. Marie is passionate about not outsourcing the manufacturing to another country and wants to keep those jobs at home! With the $25,000, we can get 1,000 paperback books printed, 500 hard cover books printed, 1,000 stuffed bears made, invest in some marketing, and throw a fabulous launch party. If we exceed our goal, our stretch goal is $50,000. With that, we will be able to donate books to public libraries, schools, and military support groups. If we exceed the stretch goal, we will definitely have even more books printed, bears made, and items such as t-shirts, bookmarks, stickers, coloring books, and other Buddy memorabilia. We'd also love suggestions from our fans with ideas for other Buddy merchandise. The more money we are able to raise, the more books will also be donated to public libraries and schools. 
    Perks
We are offering perks for the various donation levels which are noted in the Perks section. 

    How You Can Help If you're unable to contribute, we ask that you please get the word out. Share the campaign on your social media pages, talk to your friends and family about it. Even $5-$10 helps! It all adds up. Be a part of the Buddy movement and join "BuddysArmy. Buddy's story needs to get out! We want to help as many soldiers as we can! Thank you for your help! We couldn't do it without you and we are truly humbled by the outpouring of support and positivity already! Thank you from the bottom of our hearts!
Hugs,
Marie Joy Monroe and Brandon Pollard
A special thanks to Todd Gessele and Gioni Birkenfeld of Totally Inspired Media who filmed and edited the video for this crowd funding campaign! We couldn't have done it without you, Todd and Gioni!

story:
Who is the Author?

         My name is Drew Parsons, West Chester University student and an outspoken, strong-willed nerd.

          I've aspired to be an author of some sort since I was around twelve. I used to be obsessed with being hired by SEGA, and writing plots for my favorite game series. From there, I went on to become a fanfiction writer for five years, until at 18, when I decided to use my talents seriously. This, ladies and gentlemen, is the result of six years of effort into one series and the production of its first title.

 

What is CONTROL?

          CONTROL has been my passion project throughout my entire adult life thus far. A tale of a world rising from the shambles of a home-brewed apocalypse and discovering their place in reality. An introspection on the nature of what it means to be in control of anything, even yourself. A modern epic told through the eyes of everyday people forced to take up the mantle of modern gods. The beginning of all of this is wrapped into these pages.

          But of course, it cannot be completed without your help. The book is written, the cover art is made, but seeing as I'm privately publishing, I need printing funds, advertising funds, and to have my own website and online store constructed.

          Of course, if you'd like a sample of this completed book, then look no further. The first chapter is right here for you! (Mild profanity filter applied as per Indiegogo guidelines)
 

          Lightning splits shimmering skies upon the horizon of a barren, war-scarred wasteland. Clouds reflect the hue of the bloodstained soil below, flowing between cracks of dry and lifeless desert. Gravel shifts and crunches beneath the feet of marching warriors. Bodies of countless inhuman gods lay scattered across the valley in beaten heaps, as the victors stand above them. Animalistic maws grin down to fallen defenders, fangs bared and tongues rolling out in sadistic glee as they take untold pleasure in conquering the supposedly mighty ‘heroes’ of the once great United States. At the center of them all stands one lone victor towering over his greatest foe to date, his face in the dirt.

            The horned titan stands above a fallen lion, his pride now broken as blood flows from between his fangs among gags. He grips a collection of broken ribs with a shattered hand covered in a crimson gauntlet, struggling to steady his erratic breath. The bull standing over him laughs. “You’ve fought well, but this country is ours now. The government was failing already, and their last failure was to entrust you with their safety.” With a right-handed thrust, the bull stabs his hefty blade into the dirt beside his fallen foe. The dim lights of sunset through reddened sand and stormclouds reflect off its blackened edge, showing the fallen a bloody reflection of his broken army. “Now I’ll give you one last chance. You treat your battalion like family. If you care for them so much, you’ll end your life here and now, with my sword.” A sadistic grin encompasses the bull’s face, his eyes beginning to project a gentle yet eerie gray. “Then, I’ll spare the rest and let them join me.”

            The lion on his knees before the hulking horned brute struggles to push himself upright, gripping the hilt of the sacrificial blade. His eyes remain hidden by the bangs of his mane, soaked in blood and weighed down from its usual flare. He grits his teeth, his ears ringing as the trauma to his head leaves all senses dulled. The world spins around him, clouding all sights and feeling. He can barely see his comrades on their knees and laid across the scorched earth as the tyrant’s thugs hold them down. And yet, he can still hear the cries of pain and defiance surrounding him. Fallen brothers, sisters, warriors whom he’d taken in out of not obligation of any sort, but trust and compassion. He could finally hear the shuffling of gravel beneath feet before him as his opponent turned to leave. The bull was certain of his victory, certain he had already won and taken the west for himself. All that would remain would be to march eastward and capture the defenseless masses awaiting their new ruler. How many other tyrants had the lion brought to their knees? How many other cities had he freed from the chaos of this new world? Was it all for naught now?

            A chuckle escapes the lion’s blood-stained lips. “Ya know… I’ve come a hell of a long way to just get to my death bed, haven’t I..?”

 

CONTROL

Ubiquity of Chaos

Chapter 1

Anarchy Reigns

          

            “Oy, boss.” A chiseled, grizzly man in his early twenties steps through a curtain of hanging chains into what he and his companions have come to call ‘the lounge’. His tired eyes scan across the deflated bean bags and flat tires that litter the floor and an overturned cooler sitting in the corner beside multiple emptied beer cases. All of this was then decorated by a slew of oil stains, spatters of blood, a stray tooth here and there, and the occasional remains of the boss’s latest binge. Sitting upon one of these many bean bags, stacked upon a tire, was what appeared to be a man quite a few years his junior, not even a legal adult yet by the looks of him. He wears a tattered and stained black tank top, matching the darkened oil spots of his faded jeans, the ankles shredded away into a fray of hair-like white thread halfway up his shins, just above the blood-stained leather boots upon his feet. His jet black mohawk stood tall and pointed at six peaks, a detail that would normally be distracting, if not for the menace within his swamp green eyes, split horizontally into twin pupils.

            “What the hell is it now, Artie?” His voice is high-pitched, grating, yet rough and stern.

            Artie stumbles as he catches the boss’s eyes, quickly turning away and looking back out through the doorway. He can’t help but stammer under his boss’s watchful gaze. “U-Uh, we’ve found someone at the door. Probably a new recruit, but he passed out just after we’d let ‘em in.” His frantic rambling trails off as turns back to face his boss. “W-What should we do about him, Cody?”

            Cody raises an eyebrow for just a moment. It’s been quite a while since any of his subordinates, even old friends among them, called him by name. He pulls himself to his feet and steps past Artie with hands deep in his pockets. “Time to greet the newbie then. I’ve been looking forward to the next initiation…” A wide, toothy grin spreads across his face, teeth yellowed and jagged. Multiple heads turn as the heavy clicking of his boots upon the concrete floor echoes within the abandoned garage. Fools swinging from chains and drumming away at tin barrels suddenly go silent. A group of young drunks perched up on the empty lift fall eerily still from the midst of frantic laughter. As the undeniable alpha of their gang steps up, various animal traits and appendages twitch in anticipation. The occasional tail grows eerily still, feral eyes dilating as they take everything in. Claws unsheathe unconsciously as they wait to sink into anything upon an order. Disturbing clicks and buzzes echo throughout the garage.

            In the center of the room, a young man lays motionless on the floor, face shrouded by an overgrown mess of dark chocolate hair. His black jacket bore tears and holes revealing a red tee beneath, matching black cargo jeans and a pair of old, beaten sandals. A handful of cretins gathering around him dig into the many pockets of his coat, collecting batteries, an old handheld game system, some protein bars, and two old photos seemingly of their new victim with two friends in one and his family of four in the other.

              Cody snorts at the sight of him. “So, this is the little **** you dragged in, huh? He’s even younger than me…” He kicks the helpless young man in the ribs. “And got the hell kicked out of ‘im already. He’ll be useless to us. Probly just some beggar asking us to let up on the taxes.” He huffs and snaps his fingers. “Roll ‘im over, wanna get a look at this guy’s face. Might know the lil **** from somewhere.” Heeding their leader’s word, two burlier members of the group roll the new arrival onto his back, revealing a rather pasty complexion and a strong chin, barely covered in thin, sparse stubble.

            One of the women off to the side chuckles, playing with her greasy blonde hair. “This one’s just some clueless kid, kick him back to the streets boss.”

            Cody nods. “Yeah, get ‘im out. Got no use for anyone so weak.” Upon the boss’s command, the seemingly unconscious teen was heaved up by his arms, feet dragging across the concrete floor as the guards carry him back to the open garage door.

            Before the henchmen could get anywhere near the garage’s open front, a burst of crimson flame erupts from the limp captive between them, tossing the two aside in the blast. Before them now stands not a man, but a beast. His skin is hidden by a thick coat of deep brown fur marked with occasional darkened stripes, a shaggy mane across his head and framing his face. He’s held up by a pair of triple-jointed feral legs, black feline claws emerging from his toes. As the flames die down, he turns and glares into the eyes of their leader, swamp green meeting deep sapphire. “Not much for hospitality, are you? No wonder the whole town wants you dead.”

            The utterance of those words summoned down chaos. Bursts of colored flame and lightning consume the men and women scattered across the room, taking on equally if not more beastly forms, screams of rage erupting from their animalistic maws. The lion at the center of this storm of claws allows a wild grin to spread across his face. As they all take their time with delayed transformations, he kneels down to collect the photos they stole from him and dropped. Upon standing, he swings to his left and out of his upper left pocket, backhanding a man turned bipedal gecko in his face hard enough to send him barreling into one of his cohorts nearly fifteen feet away. As a set of feline claws swipe by his face, he falls onto his still outstretched left hand and swings an upwards heel kick into his assailant’s chest, sending them straight into the ceiling. As he feels an incoming burst of heat, he pedals off his hand and into the air over a wave of flames across the floor. Multiple others are caught in the attempted attack.

            Once on his feet, he launches a spin-kick into a young man’s shoulder, only to have his heel catch against their stone-covered hand. The target still skids a foot or so to his side, before a series of stones from the gravel scattered about gathers on his right forearm, forming a thick gauntlet to match the other. The feline hunter positions himself in a left-forward stance, allowing a collection of slow, stumbling blows to be thrown his way. He grows tired of it quickly and rushes past their last strike, grabbing his foe by the throat and using him as a living shield against a jet of flame unleashed from a nearby humanoid hawk’s bare hands. The meat shield screams out in pain for just a moment until he’s thrown into the pyro with enough force to generate the audible snap of breaking ribs.

            Silence falls for just a moment, until an unsightly humanoid insect with a deep tan carapace and sideways jaw dives down in an attempt of a sneak attack. His battle cry gives him away, resulting in a painful elbow to the cheekbone. They’re tossed aside through a collection of barrels and cans and barrels, causing gas and oil spill across the floor. And yet, the hunter’s azure eyes remain focused on swamp green, silence passing between the two for several moments.

            “… Alright, not bad.” Cody begins to pace. “You’ve got power. A lot more than those chumps. So I guess I can let you join as second in command.”

            The hunter snorts. “I’m not here to join, Cody. I’m here on behalf of the citizens of Spring City. The people you’ve been bleeding dry for weeks. Now, the next thing to bleed will be you.”

            The prey lets out a raspy, grim chuckle, gray flames forming around his feet. It flows in a motion akin to razors scraping past one another, sparking lightning along their edges. “You really think you can take me? News flash. I’m the strongest guy in this town, and probably for several around here. On top of that, I’ve already caught ya’ disarmed.” His eyes drift down to the space beneath the crimson hunter’s right elbow, to find nothing but a two inch stump already healed shut, unscarred and grown over with fresh fur. “Even if ya are a leftie, I’ve still got the upper hand, and one more than you.” With a sudden burst of silver fire, he emerges with rubbery, yet spike-covered gunmetal gray skin, his pupils still split sideways, and webs of skin between his fingers.

            The hunter raises an eyebrow. “Ah, a horned toad. That’s new.” He remarks as he shifts himself into a right-foot-forward stance, fist held up at hip level. “Stop yapping already and fight me, so I can get out of here.”

            That did it. The punk’s lips and brow curl into an almost painful scowl, his limbs twitching spastically. He backflips into the wall and plants his feet upon it, before kicking off and launching himself at inhuman speed. A thick layer of spikes and blades of hardened skin form along his right arm and grow outwards into a jagged two foot mass past his hand, swinging in to shred the hunter.

            Hair hangs down from the lion’s mane and casts a shadow over his eyes as he pivots to in on his right foot. He swings in his left fist at speeds the toad’s mutant eyes couldn’t track. Before Cody can register what had happened, he finds himself kneeling on the floor behind the lion, holding a broken arm. The man who broke it begins walking away with a bleeding, but visibly healing hand hanging at his side. He speaks with his back turned. “You made a lot of mistakes, Cody. First was killing the local police and taking over this town.” Cody looks up with a bloodshot glare, a constant twitch in the fingers of his functioning arm. “Next was sucking this town dry and taking everything they had to sate your own craving for power and attention.” As he walks away, back turned to the furious toad, his form is consumed in another crimson burst, returning to a human state. “Third was taking me in.” He can hear electricity sparking among the extended spikes upon his target’s back and between his horns. He ignores this and takes a moment to pick up his discarded jacket and pull it back on. “Fourth was calling me a worthless kid. I’m seventeen, damnit. And last…”

            As the young hunter steps through the door, he hears the deep sigh of a flame’s ignition, and almost immediately after, feels the gust of an explosion blowing past him. Debris and smoke follow in its wake, careening over his shoulder. Small smoldering scraps bounce off his back. “Using electricity in a room full of spilled oil and gas.”

            An exasperated breath escapes the victor’s lips and he runs his remaining hand through his overgrown hair. The gravel driveway crunches beneath his feet as flames lick at his heels and scorch the stone. “That was uneventful. Just another group of punks with big heads.” He steps out onto the side of the road and starts walking along Route 724 headed south, allowing his mind to wander over the past few months, contemplating the chaos that had consumed the world. It’s funny how one day can bring all civilization to its knees, and all thanks to its own people.  

            June 12th 2013. It had been a completely ordinary day, and yet, in an instant, all that had once been considered normal was left behind in a brilliant flash of multicolored lights across the skies. Within seconds, the heavens grew dark and foreboding as lightning tore through the air, and gale force winds rocked wilderness and city alike. Flowing lights, like color changing fire, flooded from holes in the clouds and sunk into all it could reach. Since then, names for this event have been tossed around by theorists and information brokers. Nowadays, most people call it The Breach, in lieu of any more apocalyptically inspired names.

            The moment the sky opened up, people around the world were changed. Their bones were reshaped, shrinking and growing on their own accord, as their skin and internal organs shifted to match. New limbs were grown, skin replaced with insectoid exoskeletons or scales, or covered in thick fur. Their bodies became both human and beast in one, with the advantages and talents of these creatures on a human scale, and yet, improved further. A grand step in evolution, yet no person affected was alike. Within moments of taking on these forms the many whom had fallen victim to the transformation began to instinctively trigger new abilities, powers that were far from biological.

            Most found they were faster and stronger. Others would find themselves able to control the elements or spit poisons. Equally vast were those whose powers were obscure and difficult to label. One occasion that stuck out in the wandering young man’s head was meeting a boy who could perfectly adhere himself to anything… and nothing else. Kind of a useless power, really.

            The results of these changes were almost immediate. As random civilians around the world discovered their superhuman abilities, they were put to use for fulfilling their formerly impossible desires. They felt unstoppable, and in many ways, were. Institutions and prisons burned to the ground, inmates escaped, students left without futures, businesses left unattended. Psychotic individuals now lacking any form of restriction took to the streets in mass, and with their march, society fell.

            This new way of life has become the norm in the three months since. Scavenge for food, avoid any mutants you see passing by - beings that had been since dubbed ‘Unleashed’- and hope your home remained your own. If you weren’t among those following this pattern, you were one of the many taking advantage of this world of anarchy, displaying your newfound power in order to make a living.

            The road ahead is a testament to the decay of civilization. Abandoned cars litter the streets, strewn about at odd angles. Some are crashed into one another or abandoned in ditches. A few are embedded into the guardrails. Occasionally, dried blood can be found in the seats and windshields. The bodies didn’t last long. A five foot tall buzzard atop one of the vehicles could attest to that. It ignores the vagabond with the soul of a lion as he passes. It knows better than to attack an Unleashed.

            Hours into his trek, he ventures into the borders of Phoenixville, cringing upon the sight of these all too familiar streets. Sidewalks crumbled, the graveyard to his right now in shambles, and the pizza parlor was reduced to rubble. “Damnit. Really liked their calzones.” An echoing car alarm blares in the distance, only for the battery to die out within seconds, allowing silence to overcome the urban terrain once more. His tired eyes pan to the shattered windows and broken doors, until resting upon the sight of an intact door, surrounded by boarded windows upon a backdrop of faded brick. It was the right half of one of the many duplexes lining this old street. Most of the surrounding buildings appear nearly untouched, almost like the apocalypse never happened. He ventures up to the door and kicks a few pieces of debris, scraps of metal from who knows where to fallen roof tiles. The sounds echo through the otherwise silent streets.

            By the time he reaches the door, he finds it already cracked open. A husky voice addresses him from behind it. “Alright, the hell are you doin here? Be careful with your words. I’m in no mood to deal with any threats.”


            A faint chuckle escapes the vagabond’s lips, leaning against the doorway with his left hand. “You seriously gonna greet an old friend like that, Mason?”

            Silence falls for just a moment until the door’s thrown open to reveal a tall, gangly teen with vibrant white crew-cut hair. Not even as yellowed as platinum blonde, but albino white, contrasting his earthy eyes as they fell upon his visitor. “Scott? The hell are you doing here? I thought you were dead!” He leans in the doorway and sizes up his old friend, his gaze lingering on Scott’s right side for a moment.

            Scott raises his arms in a nearly comical shrug, leaving his right sleeve to hang off his stumped elbow. “Thought I was too for a while. You gonna invite me in, or is that thick head stuck in the doorway?”

            With a roll of his eyes, Mason steps away and holds the door, letting Scott pass through, and leading to a few sighs of relief throughout the living room. His mother wearily lifts herself from her seat and wraps her scrawny arms around Scott in a tight embrace. Her own hair’s grayed quite a bit since they last met, the stress of these past few months having aged her by decades. Despite the constant sagging in her tired face, her smile is as inviting as ever. “Oh thank God you’re alive. When I heard about the massacre out there, I thought-”

            “Please, I’m fine, you don’t need to worry!” Scott slowly pries himself from her arms and removes his jacket, seeming rather practiced in functioning without a right hand as he tosses his jacket across the room and onto the coat rack by the door with his stumped elbow. Despite the faintly grim reactions of his peers, he saunters across the unpolished hardwood floor over to a nearby chair and drops into place. The dimly lit home soothes him for a few moments as he takes in the familiar scents of cinnamon and wet wood that constantly permeate this house. In spite of that, he only allows that peace and silence to remain for a few moments before getting to all the questions on everyone’s minds. “So were you all here at home when it went down?”

            Mason nods as he leans back against the wall. “Yeah… My parents and I were the only ones awake when The Breach hit. Father was out drinking.” He crosses his arms and closes his eyes, drifting into memories. “He didn’t like seeing me when he got home. Or Sadie…” He peeks across the room to his youngest sister, curled up on the couch with petite horns poking out of her hair. “Started ranting about us being demons.” He casts his gaze back to Scott. “…Had no choice in the end. He’s buried out back.”

            Scott hunches over and grunts, staring off into empty space. Mr. Bowers’ bigotry was no news to him. “So… How far into hell has this town fallen?”

            They look amongst each other for a moment before Mrs. Bowers looks to Mason with prying eyes. He sighs and paces about the room, roughly rubbing at the back of his neck as the stained floorboards creak beneath him. “Well, it was pretty far at first. People started changing, and half the town started burning. The high school was blown up a few minutes in. Apparently someone with combustion powers put in a little too much effort. Within a few days, things settled down enough for people to hide in their own homes, if they still had ‘em.” He leans against the wall with crossed arms, letting a quick flare of black and white flames surround him for a moment. “I happened to keep this place intact.”

            “Well, that explains the white hair.” Scott shrugs. “Seen weirder shit out of Unleashed before…” Scott leans forward and props himself up with an elbow on the left armrest to his chair. “Pretty sure last week I saw a guy with antennae in his dormant form.”

            Mason groans and lowers his head. “Yeah, well, it’s not as bad as Richie.” Scott’s brow furled at the mention of that name, mumbling ‘Richie Anderson’ to himself. “The dick’s been ‘roided out since The Breach and made a new home out of the bank. Rumor has it when he took over he tore the vault door off with his bare hands and flattened someone with it. But…”

            Scott knew the look on his face. That smirk spoke of rebellion. The last time he’d seen it was in the process of unleashing what had to be the best senior prank he’d ever seen, consisting of a homemade mix tape, an agent in the staff, and a misplaced key.

            Mason begins to pace. “There’s a team comin’ together. People from across the state have started gathering here, one of ‘em was even a big player in Paoli’s home team when the first raiding parties arrived. So far, they’re gathered up in a base we set up across town. Well-hidden and kind of out of the way for most survivors here. As long as we approach quietly and watch our backs, we’ll be safe from any raids.”

            Silence falls throughout the room as all eyes fall upon Scott, his own gaze falling upon something imperceptible, glazed yet focused. “Alright then...” He turns to face Mason with stone-faced determination. His limbs are loose and relaxed, yet the steel in his back and fire in his eyes speaks volumes. “Where do I sign up?”

            Mason grins from ear to ear, stepping up and taking Scott’s hand with a renewed passion and lifting him from his seat. “We’ll have to go after sunset, make sure we stay hidden. After midnight would probably be best. So, go crash up in my room for a while, and I’ll come grab ya later.” He pats Scott’s back and sends him off towards the stairs, as Scott gives him a casual two-fingered salute.

            “Thanks. Could use a rest after dealin’ with… I think was about fifteen dipshits runnin’ a gang out of a garage a town over.” Scott snorts as he marches up the creaky steps. “Over half of em bailed in the middle of the fight to save their own asses.” He yawns and trails off upon stepping into a room full of old games and consoles that no longer worked thanks to the lack of electricity. Some ornate weapons hang on the walls, most too dull to be of any use in cutting and all likely too fragile to be of any worth in combat. Chuckling to himself, he kicks off his sandals and collapses into the bed, staring at the ceiling in silence for several minutes. He hears the Bowers chattering amongst themselves below, but having finally found a peaceful place to rest, he drifts off into the deepest sleep he’s had in months.

          ...And thus begins the tale of Scott's biggest mistake and how it eventually both saves and dooms the world.

 

What is Kairos Publishing?

          My dream for a brighter future in publishing. The current industry is rife with corruption and limits the creative rights of its customers, the authors. What I intend to do is remedy that with a publishing company by authors and for authors. I'll already be making plenty off my own work. Why should I need to take so much income from another author's work? Why make millions off of what isn't mine? I see no need, and I intend to return that income to the authors. A humbler company for a fairer industry.

 

What Do I Need and Why?

          So, here's where your funding comes in.

          I'll need enough to produce a few thousand copies of the physical book for the first wave of sales. My most hopeful but unlikely goal is around ten thousand, hence the fifty thousand goal. Sadly, fifty thousand will not be enough after taxes and other expenses, but it's a good start.

          Then comes the costs of producing, hosting, and maintaining a website. This site will, at its core, be for Kairos Publishing, but will include pages specifically for CONTROL and an online store selling the CONTROL book series and other upcoming publications and products. (More on other products later)

          Other lesser expenses will also include an improved office space for managing this endeavor and producing later titles, as my current hardware is wearing is a bit thin.

 

What do I get Out of This?

          Donators will be able to recieve the following prizes for their generous donations!

  • 7$ for a pre-ordered copy of the ebook, to be recieved by email. This will be a 3rd party file rather than a Kindle file, but it will be functional on a Kindle device.
  • 9$ for a pre-release copy of the ebook, two weeks before the official sale date!
  • 16$ for a pre-ordered copy of the printed novel in paperback.
  • 20$ for a signed copy! With your help, this series may one day be big enough for those signed copies to be collectors' items.
  • 100$ for a signed copy with a personalized message!

          If I do not receive all of my intended funds, I'll still distribute what I do receive to achieve the closest possible result to what I intend. No matter the results, CONTROL will move on, and Kairos Publishing will be making its debut. What I'm asking for is simply a little help in making my grand entrance into the industry.

 

How Far Can This Go?

          As stated before, CONTROL: Ubiquity of Chaos is only the beginning of a series. Four more main series titles and three side titles are in planning, and the first sequel is already in the works. But, these books preface something even greater.

          From here, I fully intend to provide the services I perform for my own work for many other up-and-coming authors. A few are already lined up, spanning a few other genres. You can expect the next title to be a collection of high fantasy short stories by a fellow West Chester University student and aspiring high fantasy and science fantasy novelist. At Kairos Enterprises, we wont be turning authors down for not meeting a strict moral code or hidden agendas. Creative freedom will be maintained to the fullest, and no author will be turned away due to conflicting opinions. The creators will thrive here, and be encouraged to take their work beyond the literary and into other fields. There will be no arguments over rights here if you want to make a movie. We may even pitch in.

 

What's In the Way?

          The biggest thing in my way right now is funding and advertisement. I have the backing of several experienced and successful entrepreneurs, the book itself is already finished, and the reviews I have received are truly encouraging. As long as I can solve the issues with funding production and advertising my work, it should be relatively smooth sailing from here compared to being an English major at a university with papers due in every class and still managing to find time for my book.

          And those are the two places you are best suited to help. Your donations will cover the finances, and the advertising is even easier. Spread the word about this campaign, reblog it, post it to Facebook, on Reddit, or whatever group chats you may have on Skype or Discord. It's quick, it's simple, and it does just as much for me as your donations. Even if you can't donate, tell someone, and you've already helped enough for me to thank you from the bottom of my heart.

          Hopefully, with your help, CONTROL can one day be a household title, and Kairos Publishing may bring the works of many others to such a status as well.
story_txt:
Who is the Author?
         My name is Drew Parsons, West Chester University student and an outspoken, strong-willed nerd.
          I've aspired to be an author of some sort since I was around twelve. I used to be obsessed with being hired by SEGA, and writing plots for my favorite game series. From there, I went on to become a fanfiction writer for five years, until at 18, when I decided to use my talents seriously. This, ladies and gentlemen, is the result of six years of effort into one series and the production of its first title.
 
What is CONTROL?

          CONTROL has been my passion project throughout my entire adult life thus far. A tale of a world rising from the shambles of a home-brewed apocalypse and discovering their place in reality. An introspection on the nature of what it means to be in control of anything, even yourself. A modern epic told through the eyes of everyday people forced to take up the mantle of modern gods. The beginning of all of this is wrapped into these pages.
          But of course, it cannot be completed without your help. The book is written, the cover art is made, but seeing as I'm privately publishing, I need printing funds, advertising funds, and to have my own website and online store constructed.
          Of course, if you'd like a sample of this completed book, then look no further. The first chapter is right here for you! (Mild profanity filter applied as per Indiegogo guidelines) 
          Lightning splits shimmering skies upon the horizon of a barren, war-scarred wasteland. Clouds reflect the hue of the bloodstained soil below, flowing between cracks of dry and lifeless desert. Gravel shifts and crunches beneath the feet of marching warriors. Bodies of countless inhuman gods lay scattered across the valley in beaten heaps, as the victors stand above them. Animalistic maws grin down to fallen defenders, fangs bared and tongues rolling out in sadistic glee as they take untold pleasure in conquering the supposedly mighty ‘heroes’ of the once great United States. At the center of them all stands one lone victor towering over his greatest foe to date, his face in the dirt.
            The horned titan stands above a fallen lion, his pride now broken as blood flows from between his fangs among gags. He grips a collection of broken ribs with a shattered hand covered in a crimson gauntlet, struggling to steady his erratic breath. The bull standing over him laughs. “You’ve fought well, but this country is ours now. The government was failing already, and their last failure was to entrust you with their safety.” With a right-handed thrust, the bull stabs his hefty blade into the dirt beside his fallen foe. The dim lights of sunset through reddened sand and stormclouds reflect off its blackened edge, showing the fallen a bloody reflection of his broken army. “Now I’ll give you one last chance. You treat your battalion like family. If you care for them so much, you’ll end your life here and now, with my sword.” A sadistic grin encompasses the bull’s face, his eyes beginning to project a gentle yet eerie gray. “Then, I’ll spare the rest and let them join me.”
            The lion on his knees before the hulking horned brute struggles to push himself upright, gripping the hilt of the sacrificial blade. His eyes remain hidden by the bangs of his mane, soaked in blood and weighed down from its usual flare. He grits his teeth, his ears ringing as the trauma to his head leaves all senses dulled. The world spins around him, clouding all sights and feeling. He can barely see his comrades on their knees and laid across the scorched earth as the tyrant’s thugs hold them down. And yet, he can still hear the cries of pain and defiance surrounding him. Fallen brothers, sisters, warriors whom he’d taken in out of not obligation of any sort, but trust and compassion. He could finally hear the shuffling of gravel beneath feet before him as his opponent turned to leave. The bull was certain of his victory, certain he had already won and taken the west for himself. All that would remain would be to march eastward and capture the defenseless masses awaiting their new ruler. How many other tyrants had the lion brought to their knees? How many other cities had he freed from the chaos of this new world? Was it all for naught now?
            A chuckle escapes the lion’s blood-stained lips. “Ya know… I’ve come a hell of a long way to just get to my death bed, haven’t I..?”
 
CONTROL
Ubiquity of Chaos
Chapter 1
Anarchy Reigns
          
            “Oy, boss.” A chiseled, grizzly man in his early twenties steps through a curtain of hanging chains into what he and his companions have come to call ‘the lounge’. His tired eyes scan across the deflated bean bags and flat tires that litter the floor and an overturned cooler sitting in the corner beside multiple emptied beer cases. All of this was then decorated by a slew of oil stains, spatters of blood, a stray tooth here and there, and the occasional remains of the boss’s latest binge. Sitting upon one of these many bean bags, stacked upon a tire, was what appeared to be a man quite a few years his junior, not even a legal adult yet by the looks of him. He wears a tattered and stained black tank top, matching the darkened oil spots of his faded jeans, the ankles shredded away into a fray of hair-like white thread halfway up his shins, just above the blood-stained leather boots upon his feet. His jet black mohawk stood tall and pointed at six peaks, a detail that would normally be distracting, if not for the menace within his swamp green eyes, split horizontally into twin pupils.            “What the hell is it now, Artie?” His voice is high-pitched, grating, yet rough and stern.            Artie stumbles as he catches the boss’s eyes, quickly turning away and looking back out through the doorway. He can’t help but stammer under his boss’s watchful gaze. “U-Uh, we’ve found someone at the door. Probably a new recruit, but he passed out just after we’d let ‘em in.” His frantic rambling trails off as turns back to face his boss. “W-What should we do about him, Cody?”            Cody raises an eyebrow for just a moment. It’s been quite a while since any of his subordinates, even old friends among them, called him by name. He pulls himself to his feet and steps past Artie with hands deep in his pockets. “Time to greet the newbie then. I’ve been looking forward to the next initiation…” A wide, toothy grin spreads across his face, teeth yellowed and jagged. Multiple heads turn as the heavy clicking of his boots upon the concrete floor echoes within the abandoned garage. Fools swinging from chains and drumming away at tin barrels suddenly go silent. A group of young drunks perched up on the empty lift fall eerily still from the midst of frantic laughter. As the undeniable alpha of their gang steps up, various animal traits and appendages twitch in anticipation. The occasional tail grows eerily still, feral eyes dilating as they take everything in. Claws unsheathe unconsciously as they wait to sink into anything upon an order. Disturbing clicks and buzzes echo throughout the garage.
            In the center of the room, a young man lays motionless on the floor, face shrouded by an overgrown mess of dark chocolate hair. His black jacket bore tears and holes revealing a red tee beneath, matching black cargo jeans and a pair of old, beaten sandals. A handful of cretins gathering around him dig into the many pockets of his coat, collecting batteries, an old handheld game system, some protein bars, and two old photos seemingly of their new victim with two friends in one and his family of four in the other.
              Cody snorts at the sight of him. “So, this is the little **** you dragged in, huh? He’s even younger than me…” He kicks the helpless young man in the ribs. “And got the hell kicked out of ‘im already. He’ll be useless to us. Probly just some beggar asking us to let up on the taxes.” He huffs and snaps his fingers. “Roll ‘im over, wanna get a look at this guy’s face. Might know the lil **** from somewhere.” Heeding their leader’s word, two burlier members of the group roll the new arrival onto his back, revealing a rather pasty complexion and a strong chin, barely covered in thin, sparse stubble.
            One of the women off to the side chuckles, playing with her greasy blonde hair. “This one’s just some clueless kid, kick him back to the streets boss.”
            Cody nods. “Yeah, get ‘im out. Got no use for anyone so weak.” Upon the boss’s command, the seemingly unconscious teen was heaved up by his arms, feet dragging across the concrete floor as the guards carry him back to the open garage door.
            Before the henchmen could get anywhere near the garage’s open front, a burst of crimson flame erupts from the limp captive between them, tossing the two aside in the blast. Before them now stands not a man, but a beast. His skin is hidden by a thick coat of deep brown fur marked with occasional darkened stripes, a shaggy mane across his head and framing his face. He’s held up by a pair of triple-jointed feral legs, black feline claws emerging from his toes. As the flames die down, he turns and glares into the eyes of their leader, swamp green meeting deep sapphire. “Not much for hospitality, are you? No wonder the whole town wants you dead.”
            The utterance of those words summoned down chaos. Bursts of colored flame and lightning consume the men and women scattered across the room, taking on equally if not more beastly forms, screams of rage erupting from their animalistic maws. The lion at the center of this storm of claws allows a wild grin to spread across his face. As they all take their time with delayed transformations, he kneels down to collect the photos they stole from him and dropped. Upon standing, he swings to his left and out of his upper left pocket, backhanding a man turned bipedal gecko in his face hard enough to send him barreling into one of his cohorts nearly fifteen feet away. As a set of feline claws swipe by his face, he falls onto his still outstretched left hand and swings an upwards heel kick into his assailant’s chest, sending them straight into the ceiling. As he feels an incoming burst of heat, he pedals off his hand and into the air over a wave of flames across the floor. Multiple others are caught in the attempted attack.
            Once on his feet, he launches a spin-kick into a young man’s shoulder, only to have his heel catch against their stone-covered hand. The target still skids a foot or so to his side, before a series of stones from the gravel scattered about gathers on his right forearm, forming a thick gauntlet to match the other. The feline hunter positions himself in a left-forward stance, allowing a collection of slow, stumbling blows to be thrown his way. He grows tired of it quickly and rushes past their last strike, grabbing his foe by the throat and using him as a living shield against a jet of flame unleashed from a nearby humanoid hawk’s bare hands. The meat shield screams out in pain for just a moment until he’s thrown into the pyro with enough force to generate the audible snap of breaking ribs.
            Silence falls for just a moment, until an unsightly humanoid insect with a deep tan carapace and sideways jaw dives down in an attempt of a sneak attack. His battle cry gives him away, resulting in a painful elbow to the cheekbone. They’re tossed aside through a collection of barrels and cans and barrels, causing gas and oil spill across the floor. And yet, the hunter’s azure eyes remain focused on swamp green, silence passing between the two for several moments.            “… Alright, not bad.” Cody begins to pace. “You’ve got power. A lot more than those chumps. So I guess I can let you join as second in command.”            The hunter snorts. “I’m not here to join, Cody. I’m here on behalf of the citizens of Spring City. The people you’ve been bleeding dry for weeks. Now, the next thing to bleed will be you.”
            The prey lets out a raspy, grim chuckle, gray flames forming around his feet. It flows in a motion akin to razors scraping past one another, sparking lightning along their edges. “You really think you can take me? News flash. I’m the strongest guy in this town, and probably for several around here. On top of that, I’ve already caught ya’ disarmed.” His eyes drift down to the space beneath the crimson hunter’s right elbow, to find nothing but a two inch stump already healed shut, unscarred and grown over with fresh fur. “Even if ya are a leftie, I’ve still got the upper hand, and one more than you.” With a sudden burst of silver fire, he emerges with rubbery, yet spike-covered gunmetal gray skin, his pupils still split sideways, and webs of skin between his fingers.
            The hunter raises an eyebrow. “Ah, a horned toad. That’s new.” He remarks as he shifts himself into a right-foot-forward stance, fist held up at hip level. “Stop yapping already and fight me, so I can get out of here.”
            That did it. The punk’s lips and brow curl into an almost painful scowl, his limbs twitching spastically. He backflips into the wall and plants his feet upon it, before kicking off and launching himself at inhuman speed. A thick layer of spikes and blades of hardened skin form along his right arm and grow outwards into a jagged two foot mass past his hand, swinging in to shred the hunter.
            Hair hangs down from the lion’s mane and casts a shadow over his eyes as he pivots to in on his right foot. He swings in his left fist at speeds the toad’s mutant eyes couldn’t track. Before Cody can register what had happened, he finds himself kneeling on the floor behind the lion, holding a broken arm. The man who broke it begins walking away with a bleeding, but visibly healing hand hanging at his side. He speaks with his back turned. “You made a lot of mistakes, Cody. First was killing the local police and taking over this town.” Cody looks up with a bloodshot glare, a constant twitch in the fingers of his functioning arm. “Next was sucking this town dry and taking everything they had to sate your own craving for power and attention.” As he walks away, back turned to the furious toad, his form is consumed in another crimson burst, returning to a human state. “Third was taking me in.” He can hear electricity sparking among the extended spikes upon his target’s back and between his horns. He ignores this and takes a moment to pick up his discarded jacket and pull it back on. “Fourth was calling me a worthless kid. I’m seventeen, damnit. And last…”
            As the young hunter steps through the door, he hears the deep sigh of a flame’s ignition, and almost immediately after, feels the gust of an explosion blowing past him. Debris and smoke follow in its wake, careening over his shoulder. Small smoldering scraps bounce off his back. “Using electricity in a room full of spilled oil and gas.”
            An exasperated breath escapes the victor’s lips and he runs his remaining hand through his overgrown hair. The gravel driveway crunches beneath his feet as flames lick at his heels and scorch the stone. “That was uneventful. Just another group of punks with big heads.” He steps out onto the side of the road and starts walking along Route 724 headed south, allowing his mind to wander over the past few months, contemplating the chaos that had consumed the world. It’s funny how one day can bring all civilization to its knees, and all thanks to its own people.  
            June 12th 2013. It had been a completely ordinary day, and yet, in an instant, all that had once been considered normal was left behind in a brilliant flash of multicolored lights across the skies. Within seconds, the heavens grew dark and foreboding as lightning tore through the air, and gale force winds rocked wilderness and city alike. Flowing lights, like color changing fire, flooded from holes in the clouds and sunk into all it could reach. Since then, names for this event have been tossed around by theorists and information brokers. Nowadays, most people call it The Breach, in lieu of any more apocalyptically inspired names.
            The moment the sky opened up, people around the world were changed. Their bones were reshaped, shrinking and growing on their own accord, as their skin and internal organs shifted to match. New limbs were grown, skin replaced with insectoid exoskeletons or scales, or covered in thick fur. Their bodies became both human and beast in one, with the advantages and talents of these creatures on a human scale, and yet, improved further. A grand step in evolution, yet no person affected was alike. Within moments of taking on these forms the many whom had fallen victim to the transformation began to instinctively trigger new abilities, powers that were far from biological.
            Most found they were faster and stronger. Others would find themselves able to control the elements or spit poisons. Equally vast were those whose powers were obscure and difficult to label. One occasion that stuck out in the wandering young man’s head was meeting a boy who could perfectly adhere himself to anything… and nothing else. Kind of a useless power, really.
            The results of these changes were almost immediate. As random civilians around the world discovered their superhuman abilities, they were put to use for fulfilling their formerly impossible desires. They felt unstoppable, and in many ways, were. Institutions and prisons burned to the ground, inmates escaped, students left without futures, businesses left unattended.
